It was never a game, its more a memonic that teaches the relationship between the 3 primary elements Earth (rock), Water (paper), Air (scissors) and dates back thousands of years. The real question you should be asking is ... what does water do to rock? And of course the answers are water mineralizes earth, earth traps air, and air diffuses water.

I now have questions. 1) what is the smallest rock that can break scissors? And does trying to cut a rock with scissors, thus damaging the scissors, count? 2) what about the paper made of animal skins mentioned elsewhere in the comments? 3) When I was young, the rules were not taught as, "paper beats rock, rock beats scissors, scissors beats paper." Rather it went, "paper covers rock, rock breaks scissors, scissors cut paper." So there was no need to prove or disprove any discrepancies. But, are the original Japanese rules known? If so, what are they?

The way I learned RPS when I was growing up made perfect sense. We never said "Rock beats scissors", "scissors beats paper", or "Paper beats rock". Way to ignore the Japanese origins. There were two types of paper used in ancient Japan, a vellum made of sheep's or goat skin, and bamboo paper. Modern paper, as we know it today, wasn't invented (independently) in Japan until the 14th century. The game goes back to the fourth century when it was introduced to Japan's native population by Chinese Buddhist monks. Bamboo paper (Washi) and vellum are around 20x stronger than that construction paper presented in the video. Washi was more cloth like, and could be used in a variety of ways, including making rope. Modern Washi often used for origami is far thinner than the traditional Washi. You can still buy traditional Washi today, and it comes in thicknesses up to 8 mm. Washi has a tensile strength of around 2.2 lbs per mm of thickness.
